titleStmt.title: A miracle, of miracles As fearefull as euer was seene or heard of in the memorie of man. Which lately happened at Dichet in Sommersetshire, and sent by diuers credible witnesses to be published in London. Also a prophesie reuealed by a poore countrey maide, who being dead the first of October last, 1613. 24. houres, reuiued againe, and lay fiue dayes weeping, and continued prophesying of strange euents to come, and so died the 5. day following. Witnessed by M. Nicholas Faber, parson of the towne, and diuers worthy gentlemen of the same countrey. 1613, withall, Lincolnshire teares. For a great deluge, in which fiue villages were lamentably drovvned this present month.

div.head: TO MY LOVING FRIENDS AND READERS IN LONDON.
div.p: BELOVED and courteous friends and Readers, wee haue to con≈øider by this ≈øtrange di≈øcour≈øe, how ready Sathan is to take hold on vs, if wee fall from GOD neuer ≈øo little. Hee continually runneth vp and downe, ≈øeeking whom hee may deuoure: But notwith≈øtanding his temptations, which are great, the mercie of God is greater, who neuer faileth to ≈øend comfort in temptation, if we accept thereof.

Great are the examples both of Gods mercie and might, to put vs in remembrance of our ≈øinnes which are infinite and loath≈øome, wherein if wee continue, let vs vndoubtedly looke for the reward thereof, which is an euerla≈øting de≈øtruction both of bodie and ≈øoule.

Let not this which is heere declared ≈øeeme a fained fable vnto thee, but a≈ø≈øure thy ≈øelfe that all ≈øuch things are ≈øent as warnings for our wickednes, and to put vs in mind of the ≈øtay of our ≈øaluation, which
is an a≈ø≈øured faith in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus: from which piller if wee once ≈øhrinke, the Tempter is readie to driue vs into de≈øpaire of Gods mercie.

Many are the wonders which haue lately happened, as of ≈øodaine and ≈øtrange death vpon periured per≈øons, ≈øtrange ≈øights in the Ayre, ≈øtrange births on the Earth, Earthquakes, Commets, and fierie Impre≈ø≈øions, with the execution of GOD him≈øelfe from his holy fire in heauen, on the wretched man and his wife, at Holnhur≈øt in Hamp≈øhire; written by that worthy Mini≈øter mai≈øter Hilliard; and all to put vs in minde of God, who≈øe workes are wonderfull.

The≈øe and ≈øuch like examples (good Reader) warneth vs to bee watchfull for the day of the Lord which is at hand, lea≈øt ≈øodainely his wrath be kindled again≈øt vs. Let vs therefore pray to Almightie God to hold back his rodde, to be mercifull to vs, and to forgiue vs that is pa≈øt: that through the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his Spirit, wee may with penitent hearts liue in his feare to our liues end.

div.head: STRANGE NEVVES out of Sommer≈øet≈øhire.
div.p:
VPon the ninth day of Septemb. la≈øt pa≈øt, there was a Yeoman of hone≈øt reputation, dwelling in the Towne of Dichet, which is within three myles of Bruton (the mo≈øt ancient towne within Sommer≈øet≈øhire) who≈øe name is Steuen Cooper, a man of good wealth, and well beloued of his neighbours: who beeing ≈øicke, and lying in a weake ≈øtate, ≈øent his wife (who≈øe name was Margaret Cooper) vpon the ninth day of Sept. pa≈øt into Gloce≈øter-≈øhire, to take order concerning a Farme which he hath in a village called Rockhampton, alias Rockington, at who≈øe comming thither, it ≈ø√©emed al things were not according to her minde. Thus continuing there one day and ≈øomething more, ≈øhee returned home to her hu≈øband, partly agrieued at ≈øuch things as ≈øhee thought her hu≈øband might reforme, if God lent him life. Now when ≈øh√©e was come home againe to Dichet, ≈øhe found her hu≈øband recouered to an indifferent health: to whom ≈øhee beganne to v≈øe very much idle talke, as well concerning the ≈øame Farme, as al≈øo concerning an olde groate which her ≈øonne (being a little boy) had found
about one weeke before. Thus ≈øhee continued (as it were one that had beene bewitched or haunted with an euill Spirit) vntill Tue≈øday at night following, which night ≈øhe tooke her re≈øt ≈øomething indifferently vntill towards the morning: at which time ≈øhee began with much vaine ≈øpeech to di≈øquiet her hu≈øband, and to v≈øe much idle talke: but her hu≈øband ≈øeeing her in ≈øuch a minde, and finding that ≈øhee was as it were one that were de≈øperate, hee per≈øwadod her to call vpon God, and that b√©eing the creature of God, ≈øhee ≈øhould not forget to call vpon her Creatour in the day of trouble, wherefore he coun≈øelled her to pray with him, and to ≈øay the Lords Prayer after him, which ≈øhe partly did. But the Diuell, who alway doth build his Chappell ≈øo neere as hee may to vexe Gods Church, began to withdrawe her from Prayer, and to put her in minde to call in mo≈øt fearefull ≈øort for the groat which her ≈øonne had lately found, as al≈øo for her Wedding Ring, de≈øiring to ≈øee them with all ≈øpeede: her hu≈øband made no great ha≈øt thereunto, but continued in Prayer, that it would plea≈øe GOD, to ≈øend her a more quiet ≈øpirit and to ≈øtrengthen her, that faith might ≈øpeedily vanqui≈øh ≈øuch vanity in her. But the more hee prayed and per≈øwaded her to Prayer, the more ≈øhee ≈øeemed to bee as it were troubled with ≈øome euill ≈øpirit, calling ≈øtill for the olde groat, which her hu≈øband neglected to ≈øhew her: whereat ≈øhe began with a very ≈øterne and ≈øtaring countenance to looke on her hu≈øband in mo≈øt wonderfull ≈øort, ≈øo that h√©e was ≈øore frighted with the ≈øame. Then he called for her ≈øi≈øter, for that he was not able to keepe her in her bed: which when her ≈øi≈øter and other were come into the Chamber, they kept her downe violently in the bed: and foorthwith ≈øhee was ≈øo ≈øore tormented, that ≈øhee fomed at the mouth, and was ≈øhaken with ≈øuch force, that the bed and the Chamber did ≈øhake and moue in mo≈øt ≈øtrange
≈øort: her hu≈øband continued praying for her deliuerance: ≈øo that within one halfe houre after her ≈øhaking was left, ≈øhee began to tell them that ≈øhe had been in the Towne to beate away the Beare which followed her into the yard when ≈øhee came out of the Countrie, which to her thinking had no head. Then her hu≈øband and friendes wi≈øhed her to leaue tho≈øe vaine imaginations, per≈øwaded her that it was nothing but the lightnes of her braine, which was become idle for want of re≈øt. Wherefore her hu≈øband and friends exhorted her to ≈øay the Lords prayer with them, which ≈øhe did, and after tooke ≈ømall re≈øt. And thus ≈øhe remained vntill the Sunday following: in which time ≈øhe continued raging as it were be≈øtraught of her memory, which came by fits, to the great griefe of her hu≈øband, friends, and neighbours. Vpon the Saterday following there was good hope of her recouerie, for that ≈øhee in the night before had taken ≈øome rea≈øonable re≈øt: her friends and neighbours came to comfort her, yet ≈øometime ≈øhee would talke ≈øomewhat idly to them, which came by ≈ømall fittes. And vpon the Sunday ≈øhee ≈øeemed very patient and conformable to rea≈øon, vntill midnight: at which time the Candle, which was ≈øet burning in the ≈øame Chamber, was burned out. She then ≈øuddenly waking, called to her hu≈øband, and cried out, ≈øaying that ≈øhe did ≈øee a ≈øtrange thing like vnto a Snaile, carrying fire in mo≈øt wonderfull ≈øort. Whereat her hu≈øband was amazed: and ≈ø√©eing the Candle was cleane burnt out, called to his brother and ≈øi≈øter that were in the hou≈øe with other of their friends watching and ≈øitting vp, to comfort her if her extreame fit ≈øhould any way mole≈øt her, who hearing her hu≈øband call, came in and brought a Candle lighted, and ≈øet it on the Table which ≈øtood neere where the woman lay. She began then to waxe as one very fearefull, ≈øaying to her hu≈øband and the re≈øt: doe not you ≈øee the Diuell? Whereat they de≈øired
her to remember GOD, and to call for grace, that her faith might bee onely fixed vpon him to the vanqui≈øhing of the Diuell, and his a≈ø≈øaults. Well (quoth ≈øhe) if you ≈øee nothing now, you ≈øhall ≈øee ≈øomething by and by: and forthwith they heard a noi≈øe in the ≈øtreet, as it had been the comming of two or three Carts, and pre≈øently they in the chamber cryed out ≈øaying, Lord helpe vs, what manner of thing is this that commeth heere? Then her hu≈øband looking vp in his bed, e≈øpied a thing come to the bed much like vnto a Beare, but it had no head nor tayle, halfe a yard in length, and halfe a yard in height: her hu≈øband ≈øeeing it come to the bed ro≈øe vp, and tooke a ioyned ≈øtoole and ≈øtroke at the ≈øaid thing, the ≈øtroke ≈øounded as though he had ≈øtroken vpon a Fetherbed: then it came to the woman and ≈øtroke her thr√©e times vpon the feete, and tooke her out of the bed and ≈øo rouled her too and fro in the chamber, and vnder the bed. The people there pre≈øent, to the number of ≈øeuen per≈øons, were ≈øo greatly amazed with this horrible ≈øight that they knew not what to doe, yet they called ≈øtill vpon GOD for his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance: but the Candle was ≈øo dimme, that they could ≈øcar≈øely ≈øee one another. At the la≈øt this Mon≈øter, which we ≈øuppo≈øe to be the Diuell, did thru≈øt the womans head betwixt her legges, and ≈øo rouled her in a round compa≈ø≈øe like an hoope through three other Chambers downe an high paire of ≈øtaires in the Hall where hee kept her the ≈øpace of a quarter of an houre. Her hu≈øband, and they in the Chamber aboue dur≈øt not come downe to her, but remained in prayer weeping at the ≈øtaires head, gr√©euou≈øly lamenting to ≈øee her ≈øo carried away. There was ≈øuch an horrible ≈øtinke in the Hall, and ≈øuch fierie flames, that they were glad to ≈øtoppe their no≈øes with cloathes and napkins. Then the woman cryed out, calling to her hu≈øband. Now he is gone. Then (quoth hee) in the name
of GOD come vp to mee. And ≈øo euen vpon the ≈øodaine ≈øhe was come ≈øo quickly that they greatly maruailed at it. Then they brought her to bed, and foure of them kept downe the cloathes about the bed, and continued in prayer for her. The Candle in the Chamber could not burne cleere, but was very dimme, and ≈øuddenly the woman was got out of the bed, and the windowe at the beds head opened: whether the woman did vnpin the window or how it came to pa≈ø≈øe they knewe not, but it was opened, and the womans legges after a maruellous manner thru≈øt out at the window, ≈øo that they were cla≈øped about the po≈øte in the middle of the windowe, betweene her legges. The people in the chamber heard a thing knocke at her feete as it had beene vpon a Tubbe, and they ≈øaw a great fire, as it ≈øeemed to them, at her feete, the ≈øtinke whereof was horrible. The ≈øorrowfull hu≈øband and his Brother imboldens them≈øelues in the Lord, and did charge the Diuell in the name of the Father, the Sonne, and the Holy Gho≈øt, to depart from her, and to trouble her no more. Then they laide hands on her, and cryed to the Lord to helpe them in that their great neede, and ≈øo puld her in againe, and ≈øet her vpon her feet. Then ≈øhe looked out at a window, and began to ≈øay, O Lord (quoth ≈øhe) me thinke I ≈øee a little Childe: but they gaue no regard to her. The≈øe words ≈øhe ≈øpake two or three times. So at the la≈øt they all looked out at the window: and loe they e≈øpied a thing like vnto a little Childe, with a very bright ≈øhining countenance, ca≈øting a great light in the Chamber, and then the Candle burned verie brightly, ≈øo that they might one ≈øee another. Then fell they flat to the ground, and prai≈øed the LORD that hee had ≈øo wonderfully a≈ø≈øi≈øted them, and ≈øo the Childe vani≈øhed away. Then the woman being in ≈øome
better feeling of her ≈øelfe, was laide in her bed, and ≈øhee a≈øked forgiuene≈ø≈øe at Gods hands, and of all that ≈øhee had offended, acknowledging that it was for her ≈øinnes that ≈øhee was ≈øo tormented of the euill Spirit. And ≈øo God bee thanked ≈øhee hath euer ≈øince been in ≈øome rea≈øonable order, for there hath b√©en with her many godly learned men from diuers places of the Countrey.

THE VVONDERFVLL worke of GOD, ≈øhewed by a Prophe≈øie of a poore Countrey mans Daughter in GERMANY. 1613.
div.p:
VPON the fir≈øt of October la≈øt pa≈øt, 1613. There was a marriage ≈øolemnized at Ro≈øtorfe, a mile di≈øtant from Melwing, in Germany, betweene one Iames Crani≈øen, an hone≈øt Townes man: and one Margaret Hen≈ølers, the daughter of Hans Steeman of Melwing, decea≈øed. This Iames had beene ≈øeruant and Clarke, vnto the wor≈øhipfull mai≈øter George Ramyts Gentleman, the time of twelue yeeres, who was (by his Mai≈øter and ≈øundry other per≈øons of good calling,) brought to the Church, and at their returne were conducted to his Mai≈øters hou≈øe againe, who had prepared for him and his gue≈øts, a ≈øufficient Fea≈øt, at his owne co≈øts and charges: and although this Iames was but a ha≈øband mans Sonne, yet was hee beloued of the whole inhabitants, and that of the chiefe≈øt ≈øort. Thus was this Fea≈øt kept in good order, with great Loue and quietne≈ø≈øe: mixing
with their meate, hone≈øt mirth, well liked, and noted of ≈øundry Nobles and Gentlemen, beeing pre≈øent at the ≈øame Fea≈øt, and inhabiting there abouts.

The next day following, a young maide of the age of fouret√©ene yeares, beeing Si≈øter to the Bridegroome, came to the wedding-hou≈øe to her Brother, bringing with her the Daughter of one Simon Franiken of Melwing: both which after they had ≈øeene the hou≈øe, and in what order things ≈øtood, were de≈øirous to ≈øee the Daughter of the Wor≈øhipfull Mai≈øter George van Ramyttes, who≈øe name was Mi≈øtris Annys: who beeing in the Chamber, they both went to vi≈øite her, and doing their duties, they demanded how ≈øhe did: ≈øhe aun≈øwered, indifferent well. Then the two Maides ≈øate downe by her, where together they conferred of many matters, e≈øpecially, as concerning their attire and apparell. The Bridegroome, before ≈øpecified, had made his Si≈øter a ≈øilk vpper-body, with which ≈øhee had dre≈ø≈øed her ≈øelfe as hand≈øomely as ≈øhee might, and withall ≈øhe wore the be≈øt and ≈øeemlie≈øt apparell that ≈øhe had put on for that day. But the Gentlewoman ≈øeeing it, beganne to floute at her, ≈øaying: Can thy Father cloath thee thus, and ≈øeeme ≈øo poore? Alas Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe (quoth the Maiden) hitherto my poore Father hath alwaies to his power apparelled me: but this which you ≈øee, my Brother hath be≈øtowed on mee, to doe him hone≈øty at his mariage: God knoweth who ≈øhall weare it out, how long I ≈øhall owe it, or when I ≈øhall put it on again. And though wee bee poore in goods, I tru≈øt God will make vs rich in Spirit, and ≈øo ≈øhee helde her peace, departing for a fine Cake and Wine, wherewith they made merry. Soone after, the Citizens Daughter that was well apparelled (and ≈øomewhat vaine-glorious withall) ≈øaid that her mother gaue her all things ≈øhee could get,, but her Father was ≈øo hard, that ≈øhee might not weare that ≈øhe had, but was faine to k√©ep it from his
≈øight. The Gentlewoman replyed, ≈øaying: my Father biddeth me weare what I will, and if it were not for offence vnto the Nobilitie, hee would apparell mee like a Princes: and therewithall ≈øhee cau≈øed ≈øundry faire Iewels and Chaines to be taken foorth of her Che≈øts, which were very curiou≈øly wrought, and cau≈øed great admiration vnto the beholders. The poore Countrey Maide that knew no Pride, nor had any ≈øuch attire to boa≈øt on, held her peace, accounted her ≈øelfe with her pouertie, as acceptable before God, as the riche≈øt or fayre≈øt of tho≈øe fine Dames pre≈øent: ≈øaying inwardly to her ≈øelfe, God is a iealous God, he hateth Pride, he puni≈øheth the vnrighteous, he comforteth the poore, which haue no delight therein: and maintaineth them that are continually bent to the ≈øeruice of him.
After that al together had talked their plea≈øures, to their contentment: euery one ≈øeuerally tooke their leaue one of another, and after a while departed to the hou≈øes of their Parents.

The third day after this Marriage was ≈øolemnized, all the ioy was turned into heauine≈ø≈øe, for the death of two of the Maidens before mentioned: namely, the Daughter to the Gentleman, and the Si≈øter of the Bridegroome, who died both in one afternoone, betweene thr√©e and foure of the clocke. This ≈øo ≈øodaine death, brought great terrour and feare vnto their Parents, and al≈øo to the hearers thereof, in≈øomuch that ≈øome thought them to be poy≈øoned, and other gaue foorth their iudgements according to their fanta≈øies.

The next day after, preparation was made for their buriall: Nicholas Faber, Par≈øon of that Villedge, would haue had them both buried in one graue, but the Gentleman would not. Great lamentation was made for both the≈øe Maidens, the Gentleman and his friends, for the lo≈ø≈øe of his Daughter: and the Father and Mother, with
her Brother and Friends, for the lo≈ø≈øe of their godly Childe. Now the Mother of this poore Maide, vnder≈øtanding that her neighbours were in hand to winde her vp, and ≈øo to ≈øend her to the earth: came vnto them and de≈øired that ≈øhee might yet once more ≈øee her Daughter, which they willingly granted: ≈øo they went altogether to the dead Corpes, (which had been laid foorth, the full ≈øpace of two and twenty houres) and the Mother lifted vp the ≈øheete, ≈øighing, purpo≈øing then to take her la≈øt farewell, and fight of her deare Daughter, whom ≈øhee ≈øo tenderly loued. But contrarie to her expectation, and of all the beholders, her Daughter, euen as one awaked from a ≈ølumber, rai≈øed vp her≈øelfe, and with a milde and cheerefull countenance, ≈øpake vnto her Mother as followeth. My mo≈øt deere Mother, why haue you ≈øinned ≈øo ≈øore again≈øt GOD? div.head: THE OVERFLOWING OF Waters, breaking from the Seas in the County of Lincolne, with other places of the Land, this pre≈øent month of Nouember, to the great hurt of many people there dvvelling.
div.p: IF wee doe con≈øider the e≈øtate of mankinde aright, we ≈øhal find by experience how ≈øodaine is his fall, and we ≈ø√©e the man that hath liu'd many yeares, carefully getting together wealth in abundance, in a moment is vndone, and brought to nothing, as for example, this pre≈øent month of Nouember, brings vs ≈øufficient witnes, where in Lincolne-≈øhire, that plentifull country, that ≈øoile ≈øo large and full of increa≈øe, as well of Cattell, as other fowles of the earth, hath lately felt the vnre≈øi≈øting force of waters, by the raging and vnruly windes blowne ouer the ≈øea Bankes, where many hundreds of people, were euen forced by the ≈øodainnes thereof to ≈øhift for their liues, leauing all the ≈øub≈øtance they inioyed to the mercy of the commanding floods.

And now to beginne the di≈øcour≈øe of my lamentable reports, neare vnto the Towne of Wi≈øbidge, one of the principal market townes in that county of Lincolne, is ≈øituate a Village called Long-≈øutton, a place for hu≈øbandry and pa≈øture grounds an≈øwerable to mo≈øt in that country, but by rea≈øon of the mar≈øhy and fenny vallies adioining to the ≈øame, the mo≈øt part thereof hath b√©ene lately ouerflowed: for the winde then ≈øitting North and North-ea≈øt, beating the ≈øeas ≈øo violently again≈øt the ≈øhores, by which meanes the commanded waters exc√©eded their bounds with ≈øuch
force, that their mighty bankes were not able to containe them.

At the fir≈øt entrance of this watery conquerour, it is ≈øaid it apeared to the inhabitants a far of, like vnto a cloud rouling out of the ≈økies, or a ≈øtorm of raine, by the winds blowne nearer and nearer, but approching to the ≈øight of men, it ≈ø√©emed to bee a ≈øecond deluge: a feare ≈øo ≈øodaine, that well was that man that by flight could pre≈øerue his life: not one place, not one field, not one village, nor one towne receiued hurt by the ouerflowing of the≈øe waters, but many: yea, many were the lo≈ø≈øes comming thereby: for it is well knowne, and by true reports iu≈øtified, that n√©ere vnto Long-Sutten afore≈øaid, ≈øome eight√©ene or twenty villages had ≈øhare of this lamentable ≈øpoile, & as much ground ouerflowed as is compa≈ø≈øed in the circuite of ≈øixt√©ene miles, all the low parts of that country ≈øtood like the maine Ocean, or the Zurick ≈øeas betwixt Holland and Zeland, where nothing is left in ≈øight aboue waters but pinacles and Church ≈øt√©eples: ≈øo was h√©ere at that wofull time, nothing ≈ø√©ene but the vpper parts of hou≈øes, and the tops of tr√©es: the fury and ≈øtrength of the ≈øalt waters thus broke in ≈øo preuailed, that they ouerturned whole ≈øtackes and Rickes of Pea≈øe and Beanes, and carried them away like ≈øtating ≈øhips into the maine ocean.

It is al≈øo credibly reported, that aboue two thou≈øand head of cattell, be≈øides many thou≈øands of ≈øh√©epe peri≈øhed in the ≈øame floods, and no newes of them as yet to be heard of, but onely ≈øome few, ≈øcattering h√©ere and there, floting vpon the waters ten or twelue myles from the owners, the re≈øt are ≈øuppo≈øed to be born into the ≈øea, who≈øe deuouring wombe is able to drench vp all the wealth that remaines vpon the land, for the ≈øea is much more larger and richer then all the world be≈øide: therefore let vs pray that the Lord with his mighty and ≈øtrong arme, may keepe vs from the Rigour of this mercile≈ø≈øe inuades, and ≈øo ≈øtrengthen
her bankes, that ≈øhe may be kept within hir bounds, otherwi≈øe vnhappy ≈øhall we be in this Northerne part of the world, but now againe to our purpo≈øe.

At tho≈øe Villages bordering neare≈øt vpon the ≈øea coa≈øts many of the inhabitants were forced in ≈øaueguard of their liues to clime the tops of tr√©es, and there ≈øate ≈øtaruing in the cold day & night, vntill Boates came to pre≈øerue them, likewi≈øe vpon hou≈øe tops, and the Leads of churches, ≈øate both men, women, and children, who≈øe frighted friends ≈øuppo≈øed them to be buried in the d√©epe waues: but among≈øt all the≈øe lamentable reports, this one is mo≈øt wonderfull of a Lincolne-≈øhire man that ≈øwomme a long mile bearing his wife and two children vpon his backe to ≈øaue them from drowning, who≈øe loue and aduenture herein de≈øerueth a perpetuall commendation: likewi≈øe diuers men of that country were forced to ride vpon hor≈øes ≈øwimming al≈øo at lea≈øt two miles euen to ≈øaue them≈øelues: to ≈øpeake truth, in this extremitie nothing was cared for but peoples liues, wherein as yet few are knowne to haue peri≈øhed: for according to the cu≈øtome of that country, they haue boates and other meanes alwaies in readine≈ø≈øe prouided again≈øt the dangers of ≈øuch ouerflowing waters, but of goods and cattell ≈øuch a ≈øpoile was made in le≈ø≈øe then fiue dayes, that the loo≈øers thereof will hardly recouer their former e≈øtates in ≈øeuen y√©eres following; God of his mercy pitty their ca≈øes, and in his bounty relieue their wants, for great pouerty is now fallen vpon the wofull inhabitants of that countrey. Behold I ≈øay, the e≈øtate of man, one day rich, the next day poore: the one day aliue, the next day dead: no certainty of this worlds pro≈øperitie, no a≈ø≈øurance of wealth, all things variable, all in a moment de≈øtroyed.

Let vs call to minde the like mi≈øhap ≈øome ≈øixe yeares ≈øince in the We≈øt parts of England, where the waters of the Sea were violently driuen ouer their Bankes by a
South we≈øt wind, as the≈øe were oppo≈øite to them with a Northea≈øt, where likewi≈øe many a wealthy village ≈øu≈øtained much hurt, hardly recouered at this day: now Lincoln≈øhire thy ≈øorrowes may compare with theirs, the waters haue emptied thy pa≈øtures of increa≈øing cattell, as they did their fields; ≈øuch is the cruelty of this liquid element, for if it is rebell and get beyond his bounds, it is able to inuade a whole kingdome, ouer-turne Townes & Towers, and deuoure vp all liuing creatures therein remaining: let this one thing following be a ≈øufficient pre≈øident, to make knowne the ≈øtrength of the≈øe head≈øtrong waters, ≈øtraying from their ≈øoueraigne Prince the maine ocean, for the aboundance thereof came into the lowe mar≈øh grounds of that countrey, with ≈øuch ≈øodaine violence, that a ≈øtrong built hou≈øe, wholly as it ≈øtoode, without ≈øplitting or ≈øeparation, was borne like a ≈øhip vpon the waters, two miles from the place where it fa≈øt was builded, the people remaining therein hauing no hurt, but ≈øafely ≈øet vpon a hill ≈øide, and ≈øo pre≈øerued from the further danger: An other ≈øtrange accident happened in the ≈øame County. The ≈øalt waters, mo≈øt ≈øeafayring affirme, are of a greater ≈øtrength then the fre≈øh or the land water, and is able to beare vp what others will ≈øuffer to ≈øinke, ≈øo was it here approoued, for a woman lying in childbed, was borne with her child, bed and all ≈øafely floting vpon the waters, with the hou≈øe wherein ≈øhee remained lying, for her be≈øt ≈øafety, in a clo≈øe boarded chamber, vntill ≈øuch time as the waters abated and ≈øo miraculou≈øly pre≈øerued from death. It is al≈øo to bee maruailed, that at the la≈øt, when the waters fell, and returned to their owne abiding, which is the ≈øea, there were found vpon the land aboundance of fi≈øh of diuers ≈øorts, which the waters had left behind, the like ≈øeldome ≈ø√©ene or heard of: Contrariwi≈øe, the ≈øea made an exchange, and for her fi≈øh, receiued into her watery womb the like number of fle≈øh: as hor≈øe, kine, ≈øh√©epe, ≈øwine and
≈øuch like, to the great hinderance of that part of this kingdome.

I will not grieue the owners with the remembrance of their lo≈ø≈øes in other goods, as corne, hay, and other hou≈øhould ≈øtuffe: as bedding, linnen, woollen, and ≈øuch like, which the≈øe turbulent waters ≈øpread abroad, and made prizes to pilfering Vacabonds, it is a lamentable ca≈øe, when the two elements of Fire and Water gets liberty, for then is no mercy, but meere confu≈øion.

Not onely Lincolne≈øhire can complaine of the ≈øeas oppre≈ø≈øion. but diuers countries bordering vpon her ≈øhores, which the ea≈øterne part of E≈ø≈øex can well witnes: what goodly grounds and fayre pa≈øtures haue b√©en there ouerflowed: what heards of kine and ≈øheepe haue been there drowned: what long time ≈øpent for the recouery, to the great charge and halfe vndooing of the owners, nay further a hinderance to the whole Countrey.

With griefe of heart I now call to minde, the great lo≈ø≈øe and hinderance of an honourable Lord of this land, hapning this pre≈øent month of Nouember, in the ≈øaid County of E≈ø≈øex, where many a hundred akers of gallant ground, clo≈øing vpon the ≈øea coa≈øt, is quite ouerflowed, ≈øtanding now like a white Sea, hardly euer to be recouered, a lo≈ø≈øe of many thou≈øand pounds, which might haue rel√©eued the e≈øtates of many thou≈øands of poore people: God is angry with vs, in changing this land habitation, into a watery ocean, which by little and little, ≈øeekes to ≈øteale the whole earth into hir in≈øearchable and d√©epe circumference.

Goodwin ≈øands vpon the borders of Kent is likewi≈øe one of the Seas cruelties, which ≈øucking ≈øandy gulfe hath deuoured ≈øo many goodly Ships, many other breaches giues the Sea pa≈ø≈øage into the Land threatning our de≈øtruction. The wealthy Riuer Thames pre≈øents vnto our remembrance diuers violent pa≈ø≈øages of water, which
from time to time begets feare and care vnto our Country, ioyned with a continuall toyle for the recouerie.

Come nearer home to our famous Citie of London, and thinke vpon the ≈øtrange tydes there ≈øwelling, this la≈øt w√©eke this beginning of Nouember, almo≈øt ≈øtill remaining before our eyes, how at Qu√©ene-Hiue the water flowed into the Meale-market, and bore ≈øackes and ve≈ø≈øels of meale vp and downe the ≈øtr√©etes, and drowned many vaults and ≈øellers, to the great hurt and ≈øpoile of much goods and commodities. God of his mercy k√©ep vnder this outragious element, let it not gather head and goe beyond the bounds: for being kept vnder gouernment, it is a ≈øw√©ete good, and comfort to vs all, ≈øo is the element of Fire, both good being well v≈øed, and both euill if once abu≈øed, from the which if they once get command, let vs v≈øe this prouerbe or rather Prayer, from fire and water good Lord deliuer vs.
